div1.p: Fragment of newspaper article relating to details of Carter's incubation theory

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [19--]
div1.p:
Dr. Carter is a member of the
Rockefeller Yellow Fever Commission,
and in this capacity went into Mexi-
co and South America to stamp out
the disease there. That the work in
North America and South America has
so far progressed that it can safely
be prophesied that within a few years
yellow fever will be extinct on the
western hemisphere is the belief ex-
pressed by Dr. Carter yesterday.

He said that the situation is prac-
tically cleared up save for some cases
in Brazil, a few scattered areas in
Mexico and in Africa. A commission
to fight the disease in Africa will be
sent out in the spring. Dr. Carter
said he believes that in another dec-
ade yellow fever will be as extinct as
the dodo or the icthyosaurus.

Dr. Carter's discovery in 1900 of
the extrinsic incubation of yellow fev-
er led to the latter discovery by Dr.
Walter Reed that mosquitoes were
carriers of the disease.

Dr. Carter spent part of yesterday
with Dr. J. J. Durrett, superintendent
of the city health department, who
served with him in the public health
work in cantonments in Virginia,
which is the distinguished scientist's
native state.

A number of other sanitarians con-
nected with the United States public
health service were in Memphis for a
brief stay on the way back from Hot
Springs. The consensus of opinion
was that the section of the medical
society's convention devoted to ma-
larial control and study of tropical
diseases and the section of public
health work were among the out-
standing features of the convention
and attracted the attention of a
large proportion of the visiting doc-
tors from all parts of the country.
